article.description: Patrick Beverley scored 19 points to lead Arkansas to a 91-57 win Thursday night over Oakland, Mich.
article.headline: Razorbacks win behind 19 points from Beverley
article.linkText: Arkansas rolls to easy win over Oakland
article.story: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP) -- Arkansas' Patrick Beverley says getting final exams out of the way helped him focus on basketball the way he would prefer. Beverley scored a game-high 19 points on 7-of-9 shooting, including three 3-pointers, to lead the Razorbacks to a 91-57 victory Thursday night over Oakland, Mich. "I feel like I've been letting my teammates down the last couple of games, coming out real dry and not with a lot of energy," Beverley said. "Today we played as a team and our defense led to good offense." Arkansas (8-1) forced 27 Oakland turnovers, including 18 steals, to win a final tune-up before entering a tough nonconference run that precedes the start of Southeastern Conference play. "They stole the ball from us big tonight," Oakland coach Greg Kampe said. "Eighteen steals ... I've never heard of that many." Arkansas will face a pair of old Southwest Conference foes in the next two games, hosting Texas Tech on Saturday at Little Rock before traveling to Austin to face the Texas Longhorns next Wednesday. Arkansas and Texas have not met since the 1990-91 season, Arkansas' last year in the SWC. Arkansas seized control early in the first half and dominated on both ends of the floor. The Razorbacks shot 55 percent from the floor in the first half and hit 6-of-9 3-point attempts to take a 44-27 lead at intermission. Beverley was 5-of-6 from the floor with three 3-pointers and 13 first-half points. Arkansas used a 13-2 run midway through the first half, capped by Steven Hills' drop-step, two-handed dunk with 9:06 left, for a 27-11 lead. The final play of the opening period illustrated the Razorbacks' resourcefulness, with Darian Townes hitting a 3-pointer at the buzzer from the top of the key. The play was intended to go to Beverley coming off a screen along the baseline, but with Beverley covered, the ball went out to Townes. "We had a long practice this week and I think that really helped us," Arkansas forward Vincent Hunter said. Razorbacks coach Stan Heath agreed. "This is our most complete game, especially from an offensive standpoint. The shooting was great tonight. I will take that any night," Heath said. "If I could, I would bottle it up and carry it with me from game to game." Vincent Hunter and Hill finished with 11 points each for Arkansas. Gary Ervin added nine points and eight assists. Derick Nelson led Oakland with 16, while Shawn Hopes added 12 and Vova Severovas and Johnathon Jones scored 10 each.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover
